docs.snippet: It was easier in the old days to get ready for the new season. In midwinter gloom, the woman of fashion bought a cheerful new hat, with or without flowers, thereby lifting her spirits and getting a head start on spring.   Life is more complex toda...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was easier in the old days to get ready for the new season. In midwinter gloom, the woman of fashion bought a cheerful new hat, with or without flowers, thereby lifting her spirits and getting a head start on spring. Life is more complex today, or so it seems. A hat is no longer the sine qua non of a fashionable spring. Still, the need persists for something decorative as well as useful to signal the end of dreary winter weather and the advent of balmy, sunny days. But what should it be? Leading fashion designers were asked to offer their suggestions for a style, or styles, that would be (1) a useful addition to warm weather wardrobes (2) a precursor of future fashions and (3) as good a morale booster as the spring bonnet of yore.

headline.main: 20 DESIGNERS PRESCRIBE A TONIC FOR SPRING

docs.snippet: Former Secretary of State Henry M. Kissinger met Saturday with President Antonio Guzman to discuss President Reagan's planned Caribbean basin development plan. Mr. Kissinger was accompanied by the United States Ambasador here, Robert L. Yost, and ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Henry M. Kissinger met Saturday with President Antonio Guzman to discuss President Reagan's planned Caribbean basin development plan. Mr. Kissinger was accompanied by the United States Ambasador here, Robert L. Yost, and the designer Oscar de la Renta. Mr. Kissinger and his wife, Nancy, have been staying Mr. de la Renta's villa.

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: John Duka is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times. By John Duka   On Nov. 22, 1976, almost no one had heard of Perry Ellis. The eye of the American fashion world was hypnotically trained, back then, on Halston and Calvin Klein, s...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Duka is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times. By John Duka On Nov. 22, 1976, almost no one had heard of Perry Ellis. The eye of the American fashion world was hypnotically trained, back then, on Halston and Calvin Klein, shifting occasionally to gaze at Ralph Lauren, Geoffrey Beene, Bill Blass, Oscar de la Renta and other members of the fashion establishment. On that day, however, the front page of Women's Wear Daily, the only daily fashion newspaper in the country, carried a photograph with the simple headline ''On Their Way.'' Pictured were five relatively unknown fashion designers walking up Seventh Avenue, where the American fashion industry resides. From right to left, they were Charles Suppon, Regine Sicart, Thibaut Bouet, China Machado and Perry Ellis. Five hopefuls, searching for a place in the fashion pantheon and looking altogether confident that they would find one.

docs.snippet: Victor Buono, the character actor whose portrayal of a momma's boy in ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'' won an Oscar nomination in 1962, was found dead Friday morning at his home in Apple Valley, Calif. He was 43 years old.   Earlier in the day ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Victor Buono, the character actor whose portrayal of a momma's boy in ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'' won an Oscar nomination in 1962, was found dead Friday morning at his home in Apple Valley, Calif. He was 43 years old. Earlier in the day Mr. Buono celebrated the new year at the home of his brother, David, in Los Angeles. His body was discovered by a caretaker.

headline.kicker: VICTOR BUONO DIES ON COAST AT 43

docs.lead_paragraph: The seven parodies below have been taken from the newly published ''The Brand-X Anthology of Poetry,'' edited, with an amusing critical apparatus, by William Zaranka (Apple-wood Books. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.) PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY I met a traveller from an antique land Who said: Two vast and trunkless legs of stone Stand in the desert. Near them on the sand Half sunk, a shatter'd visage lies, whose frown And wrinkled lip and sneer of cold command Tell that its sculptor well those passions read Which still survive, stamp'd on these lifeless things, The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed; And on the pedestal these words appear: ''My name is Ozymandias, king of kings! Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!'' Also the names of Emory P. Gray, Mr. and Mr s. Dukes, and Oscar Baer, Of 17 West 4th Street Oyster Bay. - Morris Bishop

headline.main: MATTHEW ARNOLD ENTERTAINS AND OTHER FUN

docs.snippet: The wedding of Marie Elizabeth Ashton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.  William P. Ashton of Glen Rock, N.J., to Peter Henry Werner took place in New York Dec. 26. The Rev. Dr. Frank Forrester Church, minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, perfor...
docs.lead_paragraph: The wedding of Marie Elizabeth Ashton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Ashton of Glen Rock, N.J., to Peter Henry Werner took place in New York Dec. 26. The Rev. Dr. Frank Forrester Church, minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. S. Henry Werner.

headline.main: Marie Ashton Is Married To Peter Henry Werner
